capillary_malformation.location: Usually lateral leg, buttock; may extend to trunk
capillary_malformation.evolution: Darkens with age, may develop nodularity

venous_malformation.superficial: Lateral marginal vein (persistent embryonic vein), varicosities
venous_malformation.deep: Deep venous hypoplasia or absence in 20-50%

overgrowth.laterality: Usually unilateral, lower extremity most common

genetics.mechanism: Activating mutation → increased PI3K/AKT signaling → overgrowth
genetics.related_conditions: PROS (PIK3CA-related overgrowth spectrum), CLOVES, megalencephaly syndromes

diagnosis.clinical: Classic triad in absence of high-flow component
diagnosis.differentiation: No AV shunting - if present, it's Parkes Weber syndrome

conservative.compression: Class II-III compression for edema and VTE prevention

surgical.stripping: Contraindicated if deep veins hypoplastic (marginal vein may be only outflow)

definition.@value: Combined slow-flow vascular malformation syndrome characterized by capillary malformation, venous and lymphatic malformations, and limb overgrowth, caused by somatic PIK3CA mutations, distinguished from Parkes Weber by absence of arteriovenous shunting.

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Describe the classic triad of Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome
clinical_pearls: KTS = slow-flow (no AVM); Parkes Weber = high-flow (has AVM)
DO NOT strip the marginal vein if deep veins are hypoplastic - it may be the only outflow
High VTE risk - compression and anticoagulation important
Leg length discrepancy: treat with epiphysiodesis if significant
Sirolimus can help refractory lymphatic component

medicalCode.description: Congenital malformation syndromes predominantly involving limbs
